questions.question: Which of the following arrangements groups kitchen items by the MATERIAL they are made from rather than by their function?

answers.explanation: This sorts by function (all are used for eating/drinking).

answers.content: Metal saucepans, metal cutlery and metal baking trays together
answers.explanation: All items are grouped because they are made of metal – a common material property.

answers.content: Large stock-pot, large salad bowl and large serving spoon together
answers.explanation: This sorts by size.

answers.content: Blue plastic cups, blue ceramic plates and blue glass bowls together
answers.explanation: This sorts by colour.

questions.question: The edible ‘Ooho’ water orb is BEST described as:

answers.explanation: It has a solid film but liquid inside.
Only the inside is liquid.

answers.content: A combination of a thin solid and a liquid
answers.explanation: The orb is liquid water enclosed by a thin solid algal film.

answers.content: A gas trapped in a liquid
answers.explanation: There is no gas phase involved.

questions.question: In the ‘Easy Squeezy’ syringe investigation, which state of matter could be compressed MOST easily?

answers.explanation: The plunger would not move – solids keep their volume.
Liquids are virtually incompressible.
Air can be forced into a smaller volume, so the plunger moves down.
Only gases compress significantly.

questions.question: Name TWO observable properties that scientists can use to classify matter.

answers.content: Any two of: colour, hardness, flexibility, mass, volume, transparency, magnetism, texture, ability to be compressed, state (solid/liquid/gas).

questions.question: Which set of objects ALL share the property ‘flexible’?

answers.content: Pipe cleaners, Blu Tack, pool noodles
answers.explanation: Each item can be bent or moulded easily.
These items are rigid.
These are sticky or viscous, not flexible in shape.
They do not all bend without breaking.

questions.question: Why can’t liquids such as water be compressed easily in a syringe?

answers.content: Because the particles in a liquid are already close together and have very little empty space between them, so pushing them closer does not significantly reduce the volume.

questions.question: Draw and label particle diagrams to show the arrangement of particles in a solid, a liquid and a gas. Under each diagram list ONE property that results from that arrangement.

answers.content: 3 marks: Correct diagrams for all three states with clear labels and a linked property for each (e.g., tightly packed → fixed shape). 2 marks: Two correct diagrams and properties. 1 mark: One correct diagram and property or three diagrams with no properties. 0 marks: no reasonable response.

questions.question: Which everyday phenomenon involves PLASMA, the fourth state of matter?

answers.explanation: Steam is water vapour – a gas.
Lightning is a high-energy ionised gas – plasma.
Ice and water are solid and liquid.
These are gas pockets in a liquid.

questions.question: Toothpaste is best classified as a _________.

answers.explanation: It does not keep a rigid shape like a solid.
It does not flow freely like a liquid.
Toothpaste is a gel – a liquid containing many tiny solid particles that let it hold its shape.
Toothpaste is not a gas.

questions.question: In science, the term ‘matter’ refers to:

answers.content: Anything that has mass and takes up space
answers.explanation: Matter is defined by having mass and volume.

answers.content: Only solids, liquids and gases that we can see
answers.explanation: Invisible gases and plasma are also matter.
Not all matter can be compressed.
Natural substances are also matter.

questions.question: Which option below is NOT one of the five key properties used in class to identify gases?

answers.explanation: Air tanks feel heavier when full because the gas inside has mass.
You compressed air with the bike pump during Investigation 1.
Electrical conductivity is not one of the five properties discussed.

answers.content: Gases take the shape of their container
answers.explanation: The resealable bag in Investigation 3 changed shape as the gas filled it.

questions.question: In Investigation 2 (Waterproof Paper), the tissue stayed dry while the cup was held straight up and down. Explain why this happened, referring to the behaviour of the air inside the cup.

answers.content: Air trapped in the upside-down cup took up space and stopped the water from rising to the tissue; the trapped gas acted like an invisible barrier.

questions.question: Larry Walters’ balloons rose because they were filled with helium. Why does helium make balloons rise in air?

answers.content: Helium is less dense than the surrounding air
answers.explanation: Being lighter per unit volume than air, helium provides buoyancy.
Temperature was not the reason in Larry’s stunt.
Gravity acts on all matter, including helium.

answers.content: Helium has no mass at all
answers.explanation: Helium has mass; it is simply less dense than air.

questions.question: During Investigation 3 (Gas Bag) a chemical reaction produced a gas that inflated the bag. Which gas was produced?

answers.explanation: Vinegar and baking soda react to make CO₂ bubbles.

questions.question: When air inside a bike pump is compressed, what happens to (a) its volume and (b) its pressure?

answers.content: a) Volume decreases; b) Pressure increases.

questions.question: Describe one reliable way a scuba diver could tell whether a tank is full or empty before a dive.

answers.content: Weigh the tank – a full tank is noticeably heavier because the compressed air adds mass.
Briefly open the valve underwater and watch for a strong stream of bubbles – no or few bubbles indicates an empty tank.

questions.question: Which property of gases best explains why the smell of freshly-baked cake travels from the kitchen to your bedroom?

answers.content: Gases flow from one place to another
answers.explanation: Air currents carry odour molecules through the house.

answers.content: Gases take the shape of a container

questions.question: Which observation from Investigation 1 (Moving Air) gave direct evidence that air has mass?

answers.content: Feeling the breeze from a fan
Finding it harder to push the bike pump when you block the nozzle
Noticing a balloon pulls downward on the string when full of air
answers.explanation: The extra downward force shows the air adds weight (mass) to the balloon.

answers.content: Hearing a squeak as air leaves a balloon

questions.question: Draw two simple particle diagrams side-by-side: one showing the arrangement of particles in a typical solid and the other showing the arrangement in a gas. Label each diagram and add one sentence under each to describe particle movement.

answers.content: Teacher-assessed drawing response; rubric: • Correct close packed regular array for solid (1) • Solid particles vibrate only (1) • Widely spaced random particles for gas (1) • Gas particles move freely in all directions (1)

questions.question: Aerogel is 99 % gas and an excellent thermal insulator. Explain one way a firefighter’s protective clothing could benefit from including a layer of aerogel, and state which property of aerogel (linked to gases) makes this possible.

answers.content: A thin layer of aerogel in the suit would slow heat from flames reaching the firefighter’s skin, reducing the risk of burns. Because aerogel traps lots of air (gas) in tiny pores, it has very low thermal conductivity, so heat does not pass through easily.

questions.question: What term do scientists use to describe how ‘runny’ or ‘thick’ a liquid is?

answers.explanation: Viscosity is the measure of a liquid’s resistance to flow – how easily or slowly it moves.

questions.question: Liquids that flow quickly have ______ viscosity.

answers.explanation: Fast-flowing (runny) liquids offer little resistance to motion, so their viscosity is low.

questions.question: In the lesson investigation, which variable should students CHANGE to make it a fair test?

answers.explanation: Only one variable should change. Students compare different liquids while keeping all other conditions constant.

questions.question: Which everyday product would you predict to have the HIGHEST viscosity?

answers.explanation: Honey flows very slowly compared with the other options, so it has high viscosity.

questions.question: State TWO variables that must be kept the same (controlled) during the viscosity race so the test is fair.

answers.content: Any two of: the amount (volume) of each liquid; distance travelled; surface/tray used; angle of the tray; temperature.
answers.explanation: Keeping all factors except the liquid type identical ensures a fair comparison of flow time.

questions.question: Explain why the new squeezable Vegemite needs to have a different viscosity from Vegemite sold in jars.

answers.content: To be squeezed through a nozzle the Vegemite must flow more easily, so its viscosity must be LOWER than the jar variety.
answers.explanation: A lower-viscosity mixture will move through a tube when pressure is applied, making it suitable for a squeezy package.

questions.question: Which statement best describes the relationship observed in the Pitch Drop experiment?

answers.content: Some substances that appear solid can flow extremely slowly.
answers.explanation: Pitch looks solid, but over years it slowly drips, showing it behaves as a very high-viscosity liquid.

answers.content: Viscosity does not change with time.
Liquids with high viscosity always harden into solids.

questions.question: During the investigation you time honey, shampoo and custard down the same tray. Honey takes 32 s, shampoo 18 s and custard 25 s. Which liquid has the LOWEST viscosity?

answers.explanation: It reached the finish line fastest, so it flowed most easily and therefore has the lowest viscosity.

questions.question: Describe ONE improvement you could make to increase the reliability of the viscosity investigation.

answers.content: Accept answers such as: repeat each liquid trial several times and calculate an average; use a marked ramp to ensure the same angle each time; use precise measuring cylinders for equal volumes.
answers.explanation: Repeats and tighter control of variables reduce random error and make the data more trustworthy.

questions.question: Draw and label three liquids that have noticeably different viscosities (e.g. water, cooking oil, honey).

answers.content: Student drawing shows three labelled liquids with visibly different thicknesses.
answers.explanation: The drawing demonstrates the student recognises that liquids differ in how easily they flow.

questions.question: What happens to the particles of any substance when it is heated?

answers.content: They gain energy and move faster.
answers.explanation: Heating adds thermal energy, increasing kinetic energy of the particles.

answers.content: They lose energy and move slower.

questions.question: In the ‘Amazing Self-Inflating Balloon’ demonstration, why does the balloon inflate when the bottle is placed in hot water?

answers.content: Hot water turns the air into a liquid.
The heated air inside the bottle expands, pushing into the balloon.
answers.explanation: Rising temperature increases air volume and pressure so the balloon inflates.

answers.content: Water vapour escapes and fills the balloon with water.
The rubber of the balloon contracts.

questions.question: Explain why a very hot glass jug often shatters when cold water is poured into it.

answers.content: Rapid, uneven cooling creates thermal stress; the outside of the glass contracts quickly while the inside remains hot, so cracks form and the glass shatters.
answers.explanation: This is thermal shock caused by sudden contraction of the outer layer of glass.

questions.question: Water ‘breaks the rules’ of most substances because, when it freezes, it:

answers.explanation: Ice occupies more volume than the same mass of liquid water.

answers.content: Stays at the exact same volume.

questions.question: Why are expansion joints built into long bridges?

answers.content: To allow the bridge materials to safely expand in hot weather and contract in cold weather without cracking or warping, maintaining structural integrity.

questions.question: Draw and label a simple liquid-in-glass thermometer showing what happens to the liquid level at (a) low temperature and (b) higher temperature.

answers.content: Student diagram should show lower liquid column at low temperature and a higher column at high temperature, with arrows or labels indicating expansion when heated.
